channel.title: Images in java
channel.description:
How do you implement images in java?
I was thinking in the context of in private servers, when you click a stat and you get the info menu that pops up, in real Runescape it has pictures relating to the info. :)
Thanks. :)

item.title: Images in java
item.dc:creator: @Pwnd Pwnd
item.description:
@Pwnd wrote:

“The only reason Java is slow for using graphics is that it does not render graphics using a lower-level graphics API such as Direct3D or OpenGL.”
Although it can

Read full topic

item.title: Images in java
item.dc:creator: @k00dr k00dr
item.description:
@k00dr wrote:

biggmax:

You obviously don’t know how Java handles images then.

You obviously don’t know either.

biggmax:

I don’t know if they fixed the problem, but it used to load your images and such into RAM which of course took up extreme resources, obviously.

Yes, because, instead of buffering them, reading them straight from the HD every time they’re needed is so much faster!!! :rolleyes:

biggmax:

Even if that is fixed, Java is still not as good at handling images because that is not what it was made for. Java was made just to go into different hardware things as a cross platform tool, not something for intense GUI or other graphics.

Ignorance strikes when you’d least expect it!
The only reason Java is slow for using graphics is that it does not render graphics using a lower-level graphics API such as Direct3D or OpenGL.

While you’re partly right about Java being slow, you should check out the Java Quake-engine, Jake, along with the benchmarks.
If Jagex used native, third party code in Runescape, it would, for sure, run much faster and they could improve the graphics.

(Third party code wasn’t mentioned because Jagex couldn’t code)

Read full topic

item.title: Images in java
item.dc:creator: @pplsuqbawlz pplsuqbawlz
item.description:
@pplsuqbawlz wrote:

[quote=“Pwnd, post:7, topic:31779”][quote author=k00dr link=topic=46229.msg570291#msg570291 date=1165238948]

Java is not very good at handling images. Hence shitty RS graphics

I sense great ignorance.
[/quote]As do I. :/[/quote]

And I.

biggmax:

You obviously don’t know how Java handles images then. I don’t know if they fixed the problem, but it used to load your images and such into RAM which of course took up extreme resources, obviously. Even if that is fixed, Java is still not as good at handling images because that is not what it was made for. Java was made just to go into different hardware things as a cross platform tool, not something for intense GUI or other graphics.

The Java platform was initially developed to address the problems of building software for networked consumer devices. It was designed to support multiple host architectures and to allow secure delivery of software components. To meet these requirements, compiled code had to survive transport across networks, operate on any client, and assure the client that it was safe to run.
[hr]
Straight from the jvm specs. Stop making up s**t as you go along.

Read full topic

item.title: Images in java
item.dc:creator: @Smegman Smegman
item.description:
@Smegman wrote:

White Castle:

Well I don’t know about painting directly onto the RS client, but you should take a look at the Graphics, BufferedImage, and ImageIO classes. ImageIO is used to read image files into BufferedImages, and Graphics is used to paint BufferedImages onto GUI’s. :]

could just use new Image(url/path/file)

Read full topic

item.title: Images in java

item.description:
@White_Castle wrote:

Well I don’t know about painting directly onto the RS client, but you should take a look at the Graphics, BufferedImage, and ImageIO classes. ImageIO is used to read image files into BufferedImages, and Graphics is used to paint BufferedImages onto GUI’s. :]
